questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GCT

 

GIANT CELL TUMOUR (GCT)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Difference between Aneurysmal bone cyst and GCT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. These benign tumors are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are considered to be congenital, but not all of them are diagnosed at birth. Only about 40% of dermoid cysts are diagnosed at birth, while about 60% are diagnosed by five years of age. The dermoid cysts usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. Dermoid cysts occur most commonly on the head and neck. The etiology of dermoid cysts remains mostly unknown. These occur when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development. In the head and neck region, dermoid cysts can most commonly be seen in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • Lower end femur is Mc site for:
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis

questions.text: In indirect inguinal hernia surgery, which nerve is most commonly injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genitofemoral

 

In the context of Lichtenstein's hernia repair, which is an open mesh repair for inguinal hernias, the ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely to be injured, it was not listed as an option in this question. Therefore, the genitofemoral nerve is the best answer among the given choices.

 

This is because the genitofemoral nerve runs within the spermatic cord, which can be manipulated during the surgery. During the separation of the hernia sac from the spermatic cord, there is a risk of injuring the genitofemoral nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral: The femoral nerve is too large and lies deeper within the body, making it less likely to be injured during an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Obturator: The obturator nerve is not typically associated with inguinal hernia anatomy and is not at risk during these surgeries.

 

Option D. Pudendal: The pudendal nerve is related to the pelvic region and is not typically involved in the anatomy of an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In open inguinal hernia repairs, particularly Lichtenstein's hernia repair, the ilioinguinal nerve >> genitofemoral nerve is at risk of injury due to its location within the spermatic cord and very rarely iliohypogastric nerve can be injured.

 

In laparoscopic hernia repair, there is a risk of injuring nerves such as the lateral cutaneous nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve, and femoral nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is measured by the device shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

 

  • Oxygen saturation (often referred to as SpO2) is the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to the total hemoglobin (unsaturated + saturated) in the blood.
  • The device measures this by non-invasively detecting the color change in blood as it binds oxygen.
  • The image displays a reading of "98%", which is consistent with an SpO2 reading. Thus, this option is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxygen content of the blood:

 

  • This refers to the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood plus any oxygen dissolved directly in the blood.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the total oxygen content of the blood. They only measure the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Partial pressure of oxygen:

 

  • Partial pressure of oxygen (often referred to as PaO2) is the pressure exerted by oxygen in the blood. It's typically measured using an arterial blood gas analysis.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure PaO2.

 

Option D. Amount of inspired oxygen:

 

  • This refers to the concentration of oxygen that a person is inhaling, often given as a percentage or fraction (FiO2).
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the amount of inspired oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulse oximetry measures the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of hemoglobin in the blood using the principles of Beer Lambert’s law and plethysmography.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented with generalized fatigue and lethargy. Her general examination revealed a few superficial lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions. Labs – TC: 7400, Hb: 12.8 g/dL, and Platelets: 244,000. She had a normal DC and lymph node biopsy revealed architectural distortion, infiltration with cells with indented nucleus, and prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. Immunophenotyping showed CD10 and Bcl2 were positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Follicular Lymphoma

 

The diagnosis of follicular lymphoma is supported by several key features in this patient's presentation and pathology findings:

 

  • Architectural distortion and infiltration with atypical cells: These findings on lymph node biopsy are consistent with follicular lymphoma.
  • Immunophenotyping: The presence of CD10 and Bcl2 positivity is characteristic of follicular lymphoma. CD10 is a marker indicating origin from the germinal center, and Bcl2 positivity suggests the presence of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2, which is a hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkitt Lymphoma: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with c-myc overexpression due to the t(8;14) translocation. It often presents with a high proliferation index and does not typically express Bcl2.

 

Option B. Hodgkin Lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Sometime, PD1 overexpression. Immunophenotyping usually shows CD15 and CD30 positivity, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Option C. Mantle Cell Lymphoma: Mantle cell lymphoma is characterized by cyclin D1 overexpression due to the t(11;14) translocation. It is usually CD5 and cyclin D1 positive, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma often presents with lymphadenopathy and generalized symptoms such as fatigue. Key diagnostic features include CD10 and Bcl2 positivity on immunophenotyping, reflecting its germinal center origin and overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2.

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 4-8%

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is higher than in non-consanguineous marriages. The risk depends on several factors, such as the prevalence of genetic diseases in the population, the degree of consanguinity, and the genetic makeup of the couple.

 

The estimated risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population's risk of around 2-4%. However, the risk can vary widely depending on the specific genetic diseases and the population's prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is estimated to be around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population risk of approximately 2-4%.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of a child undergoing inguinal hernia repair is shown, with a marked vein in the spermatic cord. What is the likely structure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular vein

 

During an open inguinal hernia repair, especially in the context of congenital hernias, the structures encountered within the spermatic cord are crucial for identification and preservation. The testicular vein is one of the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord, alongside the testicular artery and vas deferens. This vein is responsible for draining blood from the testes and is often seen during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

In the provided intraoperative image, the marked structure is consistent with the testicular vein due to its anatomical position and its association with the spermatic cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: The femoral vein lies posterior to the inguinal canal and is not encountered during an open inguinal hernia repair. It is located within the femoral triangle and is not related to the spermatic cord.

 

Option B. Obturator vein: The obturator vein is also located posterior to the inguinal canal, passing through the obturator foramen. It is not visible or involved in inguinal hernia repairs as it lies deep in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Inferior epigastric vein: The inferior epigastric vein is positioned anterior to the peritoneum and supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It does not travel within the spermatic cord and would not be seen during an open hernia repair involving the spermatic cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an open inguinal hernia repair, the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord are the testicular veins. Other veins such as the femoral, obturator, and inferior epigastric veins are located posterior to the inguinal canal and are not seen within the spermatic cord during such procedures.

questions.text: Marker for ectopic pregnancy is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

The correct answer is Beta hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin). Beta hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta during pregnancy. In the context of an ectopic pregnancy, which is a pregnancy located outside the uterine cavity (commonly in the fallopian tubes), the measurement of Beta hCG levels is crucial for diagnosis and management.

 

Beta hCG: In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, Beta hCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours. In ectopic pregnancies, these levels usually rise more slowly. Additionally, Beta hCG levels are used to determine the mode of management for unruptured ectopic pregnancies (medical, surgical, or expectant management) and to assess the discriminatory zone, which is the level of Beta hCG at which an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estradiol: This is a form of estrogen, a hormone involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy, but it is not a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option C. Progesterone: This hormone supports the early stages of pregnancy by preparing the uterine lining for implantation, but it is not specifically used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Estriol: Another form of estrogen produced during pregnancy, it is not used as a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is the primary marker used to diagnose and manage ectopic pregnancies, providing essential information about pregnancy location and viability.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of thromboangitis obliterans except:(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absence of popliteal pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Thromboangitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) classically presents with a triad of symptoms including intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. Buerger's disease typically affects small and medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery rather than the popliteal artery itself. The disease primarily affects young male smokers under 40 years of age. The popliteal pulse is usually preserved in Buerger's disease, as the pathology affects more distal vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raynaud's phenomenon - This is part of the classic triad of Buerger's disease, characterized by cyclical color changes in digits upon exposure to cold, stress, or vibratory tools due to vasospasm.

 

Option B. Claudication of extremities - Intermittent claudication is a core feature of Buerger's disease and part of the classic triad.

 

Option D. Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis - This is another component of the classic triad of Buerger's disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Buerger's disease (thromboangitis obliterans) typically affects small to medium-sized arteries distal to the popliteal artery, presenting with the classic triad of intermittent claudication, superficial thrombophlebitis, and Raynaud's phenomenon, while preserving more proximal pulses such as the popliteal pulse.

questions.text: Which of the following is contra-indicated in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enalapril

 

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy because it causes fetal renal hypoplasia or agenesis. This leads to early-onset oligohydramnios due to reduced fetal urine production. Both ACE inhibitors and ARBs (Angiotensin Receptor Blockers) are teratogenic drugs that should not be used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-methyl dopa: Incorrect because it is a safe antihypertensive drug that is safe to use during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Incorrect because it is a calcium channel blocker that can be safely used to treat hypertension during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Incorrect because it is a combined alpha and beta blocker that is considered safe and is commonly used to treat hypertension during pregnancy. It is the drug of choice in hypertension in pregnancy. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

ACE inhibitors and ARBs are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy as they cause fetal renal hypoplasia/agenesis leading to oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Which of the following components of innate immunity are active against viral cells? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Natural Killer (NK) cells

 

Explanation:


Natural Killer (NK) cells are important components of innate immunity that play a crucial role in the early defense against viral infections. They are cytotoxic lymphocytes that recognize and kill virus-infected cells without prior sensitization. NK cells selectively kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells through direct cytotoxicity. They are activated by interferons, which are antiviral proteins produced during viral infections, enhancing their ability to identify and eliminate virally compromised cells.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Cytotoxic T lymphocytes - These are components of adaptive immunity, not innate immunity. They require prior sensitization and recognize specific viral antigens presented by MHC-I molecules.
  • Option C. B lymphocytes - These cells are part of adaptive immunity and are responsible for humoral immune responses. They produce antibodies after differentiation into plasma cells following antigen exposure.
  • Option D. Memory B lymphocytes - These are specialized B cells that remain after initial adaptive immune response and provide rapid secondary responses upon re-exposure to the same antigen. They are part of adaptive immunity, not innate immunity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

NK cells are part of innate immunity and provide early defense against viral infections by directly killing virus-infected cells without requiring prior sensitization, unlike the other cell types that are components of adaptive immunity.

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds
Secondary and Tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tertiary structure is three dimensional

 

Explanation:

 

The tertiary structure of proteins refers to the overall three-dimensional arrangement of a polypeptide chain, shaped by various interactions including hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and van der Waals forces. This structure is crucial for the protein's functional specificity, allowing the precise positioning of amino acid side chains necessary for biological activity. The three-dimensional nature of tertiary structure is essential for the functionality of enzymes and other proteins in biological systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary, secondary, and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation: Denaturation typically affects secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures, but the primary structure, which is the sequence of amino acids linked by peptide bonds, remains intact. Therefore, this statement is partially correct but not entirely.

 

Option C. Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds: Disulphide bonds primarily stabilize tertiary and sometimes quaternary structures by forming covalent links between different parts of the protein or between different protein subunits. Secondary structures like alpha-helices and beta-sheets are primarily stabilized by hydrogen bonds.

 

Option D. Secondary and Tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence: While this statement holds truth in that the primary sequence does dictate the secondary and tertiary structures due to the chemical properties of the amino acids involved, it's not the complete answer regarding the "true" statement sought by the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Structure of proteins –

 

  1. Primary structure of protein means the order of amino acids in the polypeptide chain and the location of disulfide bonds, if any.
  2. Secondary structure is the formed by folding of primary structure by hydrogen bonding between various residues. Example alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends
  3. Tertiary structure denotes the overall 3D arrangement formed by interactions of the various regions, or domains of a single polypeptide chain. The tertiary structure is maintained by noncovalent interactions between amino acid residue such as hydrophobic bonds, electrostatic bonds and van der Waals forces.
  4. Quaternary structure results when the proteins consist of two or more polypeptide chains held together by noncovalent forces like hydrogen bonds, electrostatic bonds, hydrophobic bonds and van der Waals forces.

 

There will be nonspecific alterations in secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures of protein molecules. Primary structure is not altered during denaturation.

questions.text: When does stranger anxiety appear in a child? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6-7 months

 

Stranger anxiety typically emerges by 6-7 months. At this age, infant also can transfer objects from one hand to another.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-10 months: Sitting without support comes by eight months

 

Option C. 12 months: A Baby can independently stand by 12 months

 

Option D. 15 months: A baby can independently walk by 15 months and run by 18 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stranger anxiety typically emerges by 6-7 months of age.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heart failure

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are indicative of congestive heart failure (CHF), specifically biventricular failure. The elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema are typical signs of right heart failure, which suggests poor venous return management by the heart. Additionally, the presence of crackles at the lung bases points to left ventricular failure, which often presents with pulmonary congestion due to backflow of blood into the pulmonary circulation. This combination points to heart failure involving both the left and right sides of the heart (biventricular failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: While this condition can cause symptoms of heart failure, the presentation would typically include other specific signs such as a systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border and possibly signs of dynamic outflow obstruction, which are not specifically mentioned here.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation could present with symptoms similar to heart failure; however, a hallmark sign would be a pan-systolic murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla, which isn't mentioned. The systemic signs such as hepatomegaly and ascites are less commonly associated with isolated mitral regurgitation unless it has led to significant heart failure.

 

Option D. Portal hypertension: This condition would explain hepatomegaly and ascites but would not typically include pulmonary symptoms like crackles at the lung bases or findings like elevated JVP and positive hepatojugular reflux without concurrent heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which of the following is the most likely primary cause? (NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

 

Enlargement of the inguinal lymph node is most commonly caused by the anal canal below the dentate line (which marks the border between the anal canal and rectum) goes into the inguinal lymph nodes. As a result, anal cancer occurring below the dentate line can lead to the enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes.

 

However, lymphatics from the anal canal above the dentate line (i.e., the rectum) drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes through superior rectal lymphatics.

 

Anal Cancer:  A malignancy that originates in the anal canal or anal margin.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage from the anal canal is to the inguinal lymph nodes. Hence, an enlarged inguinal lymph node can indicate the spread of a tumor from the anal region.
  • Clinical Relevance: Patients with anal cancer may present with anal bleeding, pain, or itching. Inguinal lymph node enlargement is an important sign to check for, as it indicates lymphatic spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the testes.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Therefore, testicular tumors typically spread first to these nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While testicular cancer can metastasize to the inguinal lymph nodes, it's an unusual pathway and typically occurs after a surgical procedure in the groin, which can disrupt the typical lymphatic drainage patterns.

 

Option C. Sigmoid Colon Cancer: Malignancy that arises from the sigmoid portion of the colon.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the sigmoid colon is to the colic nodes and then to the inferior mesenteric nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Inguinal lymph node enlargement is not a typical early site of metastasis for sigmoid colon cancer. More common metastatic sites include the liver and lungs.

 

Option D. Prostate Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the prostate gland.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the prostate is to the internal iliac lymph nodes and then to the external iliac nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While it's possible for prostate cancer to metastasize to the inguinal nodes, it's not the typical pattern of lymphatic spread. Symptoms of prostate cancer include urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty starting and maintaining a steady stream of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A worker in an industry for the last 20 years develops dry cough and chest tightness. He had the following finding in his pulmonary biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asbestosis

 

The biopsy image and clinical history suggest a diagnosis of asbestosis. Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by prolonged inhalation of asbestos fibers, commonly seen in workers exposed to construction, shipyard, or insulation industries.

 

The characteristic finding in the biopsy is the presence of asbestos bodies, which appear as beaded or dumbbell-shaped fibers coated with iron-rich proteinaceous material, giving a beaded appearance.

 

 

This is the key diagnostic feature that differentiates asbestosis from other pneumoconioses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Typically occurs in workers exposed to silica dust, such as those in mining, sandblasting, or construction. It is characterized by nodular fibrosis in the upper lobes and does not show the beaded appearance of asbestos fibers on biopsy.

 

Option B. Anthracosis: Also known as coal worker’s pneumoconiosis, this condition results from the inhalation of coal dust. It presents with black lung tissue and anthracotic pigment but lacks the distinct asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Option C. Berylliosis: Caused by inhalation of beryllium particles, typically affecting workers in the aerospace, electronics, or manufacturing industries. It presents with non-caseating granulomas on biopsy, not the beaded asbestos fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is characterized by the presence of asbestos bodies with a beaded or dumbbell appearance on lung biopsy, often seen in workers with long-term exposure to asbestos fibers.

questions.text: In the presented spirometry image, what term corresponds to the point labelled as 'F'? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced vital capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The spirometry diagram illustrates various lung volumes and capacities –

 

The point labelled 'F' corresponds to the forced vital capacity (FVC), which is the maximum amount of air a person can forcibly exhale from their lungs after taking the deepest breath possible. It includes the tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV).

 

In this context:

 

  • Tidal Volume (TV): The amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing (A).
  • Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV): The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation (B).
  • Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): The additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation (C).
  • Forced Vital Capacity (FVC): The total volume of air that can be exhaled forcefully after taking a deep breath (TV + IRV + ERV) (F).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Expiratory reserve volume: This is the additional volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled after normal exhalation, represented by 'C' in the diagram.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: This is the total volume of air in the lungs after a maximum inhalation, including the residual volume. It is not represented by 'F'.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: This is the total volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal exhalation, represented by 'D' in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spirometry diagram

questions.text: Cogwheel sign on ultrasound is seen in? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrosalpinx

 

The cogwheel sign on ultrasound is a classic appearance seen in hydrosalpinx, which is a condition characterized by the dilation of the fallopian tube filled with serous fluid. This appearance occurs due to the presence of longitudinal folds within the dilated tube, giving a cogwheel-like projection visible on a cross-sectional ultrasound image. The cogwheel sign is highly suggestive of a chronic hydrosalpinx and helps differentiate it from other adnexal pathologies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cancer: Ovarian cancer can present with a variety of ultrasound findings, such as complex cystic structures or solid masses, but the cogwheel sign is not associated with ovarian cancer.

 

Option C. Endometriosis: Endometriosis may appear on ultrasound as ovarian endometriomas, commonly called "chocolate cysts," which have a homogenous ground-glass appearance. The cogwheel sign is not typical of endometriosis.

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, or mature cystic teratomas, have characteristic appearances such as echogenic nodules, calcifications, and sometimes the "tip of the iceberg" sign on ultrasound. The cogwheel sign does not pertain to dermoid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cogwheel sign on ultrasound is a key diagnostic feature of hydrosalpinx, representing the cross-sectional view of a dilated fallopian tube with internal folds.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-45 dB

 

The given clinical scenario of hearing loss with a negative Rinne at 256 Hz and 512 Hz and positive Rinne at 1024 Hz indicates air conduction and bone conduction gap of 30-45 dB.

 

  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz tuning fork (TF) but positive for 512Hz tuning fork → approximate hearing loss will be 20-30dB.
  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz & 512Hz TF but positive for 1024Hz TF → approximate hearing loss will be 30–45dB
  • Rinne’s negative for all 256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz → approximate hearing loss will be 45-60dB.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Menke’s disease

 

  • Menke's disease, also known as Menkes Kinky Hair syndrome, is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene is crucial for the absorption and distribution of copper in the body. The mutation leads to reduced intestinal absorption of copper, resulting in low serum copper levels. This deficiency affects multiple systems, including neurodevelopment and connective tissue maintenance, often leading to severe developmental delay and life expectancy that rarely exceeds early childhood (Children die within 5 years). The condition is also associated with characteristic brittle, kinky hair, and growth retardation.
  • MCC: CVS-Aneurysmal dissection/Cardiac rupture

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This is a liver disorder characterized by chronic jaundice and does not involve ATP7A or copper metabolism.

 

Option B. Wilson's disease: Although related to copper metabolism, Wilson's disease is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not ATP7A, leading to copper accumulation in tissues.

 

Option D. Gilbert's syndrome: This is a common hereditary condition that affects bilirubin metabolism, unrelated to copper levels or ATP7A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke's disease is characterized by a genetic mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to poor copper absorption and severe systemic deficiencies, notable for its profound impact on early development and survival.

 

Reference - Harrison/Chap 333.

questions.text: What type of sanitation facilities should be provided for the refugees returning from war in a camp? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trench latrine

 

For temporary sanitation facilities in refugee camps, the recommended options are shallow trench latrines, deep trench latrines, pit latrines, and borehole latrines. Among the given choices, the "trench latrine" option is the most appropriate for providing sanitation facilities to refugees returning from war in a camp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pit method - This option is incorrect because the " Pit method " is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps

 

Option B. Dumping method - This option is incorrect because the "dumping method" is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps.

 

Option D. Aqua privy - Aqua privies, which are similar to septic tanks, are useful at the family level but not recommended for temporary refugee camps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When providing temporary sanitation facilities for refugees in camps, trench latrines (either shallow or deep) are the recommended option, as they are suitable for short-term use and can be easily set up in such situations.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant Melanoma

 

The given image showing a benign proliferation of Nevus (type of melanocytes) in a child points to diagnosis of congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Characteristics of Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

  • Seen since birth
  • Black-colored palpable lesion with well-defined borders
  • Surface is rough, hair
  • If > 20cm – giant congenital melanocytic nevus
  • Risk of melanoma is present

 

Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) can be associated with various complications, some of which include:

 

  1. Risk of Melanoma: Individuals with CMN have an increased risk of developing melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This risk is particularly higher in cases of giant congenital melanocytic nevi (GCMN)
  2. Neurocutaneous Melanosis: CMN can be linked to neurocutaneous melanosis, a condition where melanocytes are found in the central nervous system. This condition can lead to neurological issues and requires careful monitoring and management
  3. Proliferative Nodules: In some cases, CMN may develop proliferative nodules, which are areas of increased pigmentation and growth within the nevus. These nodules should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: This is characterized by clouding of the lens within the eye, leading to a decrease in vision. It is not related to skin lesions such as a congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Option B: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) often leads to secondary glaucoma due to vascular malformations affecting eye drainage, with facial involvement increasing the risk.

 

SWS presents clinically as Port wine stain.

 

Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Managing SWS-related glaucoma requires a multidisciplinary approach and regular eye exams for early detection and vision preservation.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common form of skin cancer, often associated with long-term sun exposure. It typically appears as a raised, pearly bump and does not usually develop from congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital melanocytic nevi, especially larger ones, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Monitoring and possibly biopsy of suspicious changes within these nevi are important for early detection of malignant transformation.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page number 75.9 to 75.14 73.2, 73.3

choices.text: D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with seizures. His past history is significant for an episode of fever with rash at 1 year of age which resolved spontaneously. What is the most helpful investigation to diagnose his condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgG measles in CSF

 

This patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), also known as Dawson disease, which is caused by infection with the measles virus. The CSF anti-measles antibodies - IgG antibodies will be elevated and hence, it is the most helpful investigation to diagnose this condition.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis: Mesial temporal lobe sclerosis is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy, not SSPE. It involves scarring in the temporal lobe but is not typically seen in SSPE.

 

Option C. IgM measles in CSF: IgM antibodies indicate a recent infection. In SSPE, the infection occurred years earlier, so IgG antibodies, not IgM, would be elevated in the CSF.

 

Option D. D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF: D C1Q4 antibodies are not relevant to the diagnosis of SSPE. These antibodies are associated with complement component 1q deficiency, which is linked to autoimmune conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), elevated CSF anti-measles IgG antibodies are key for diagnosis.

questions.text: Under Integrated Disease Surveillance Program, which of the following diseases are covered under Sentinel surveillance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HIV and HBV

 

IDSP has three types of surveillance:

 

  1. Regular surveillance: Covers common diseases like malaria, dengue, TB, URI, typhoid, cholera, leptospirosis, plague, road traffic accidents, meningococcal meningitis, and viral hemorrhagic fevers
  2. Sentinel surveillance: Covers HIV, hepatitis B virus (HBV), hepatitis C virus (HCV), along with air quality and water quality monitoring
  3. Periodic surveys: For non-communicable disease risk factors and anthropometry

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. TB and URI: Incorrect as these diseases are covered under regular surveillance, not sentinel surveillance 

 

Option B. Malaria and Dengue: Incorrect as these vector-borne diseases are covered under regular surveillance 

 

Option C. Cholera and Typhoid: Incorrect as these water-borne diseases are covered under regular surveillance

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under IDSP, sentinel surveillance specifically covers HIV, HBV, HCV, and environmental factors like air and water quality.

 

Integrated diseases surveillance project (IDSP)

 

Encompasses

questions.text: The predominant differentiation in Kaposi's sarcoma is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Lymphatic

 

Explanation: 

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV, also known as human herpesvirus 8 [HHV8]). The predominant differentiation in KS is lymphatic in nature, which is evident from its histology and pathogenesis. While Kaposi sarcoma has features of both blood vessel and lymphatic differentiation, the predominant endothelial differentiation is lymphatic, which is consistent with the virus's tropism for lymphatic endothelium. This explains why KS can arise in settings of lymphedema (as in the Steward-Treves syndrome) and is classified as a lymphangiosarcoma in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neural - Kaposi sarcoma does not show neural differentiation. Neural differentiation is seen in tumors like schwannomas and neurofibromas, which arise from neural sheath cells.

 

Option C. Muscular - While blood vessels contain smooth muscle cells, Kaposi sarcoma is primarily of endothelial origin with lymphatic differentiation. Tumors with muscular differentiation include leiomyomas and leiomyosarcomas.

 

Option D. Epithelial - Kaposi sarcoma shows endothelial rather than epithelial differentiation. Epithelial differentiation is characteristic of carcinomas, which arise from epithelial tissues like skin or glandular structures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kaposi sarcoma shows predominantly lymphatic endothelial differentiation and is caused by KSHV/HHV8 infection, appearing in four clinical variants: classic, endemic African, transplantation-associated, and AIDS-associated, with the latter being the most aggressive form.

choices.text: Low TSH levels
Low free T4 levels
Low serum T3 levels
Radioactive iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Low TSH levels
 

Grave’s disease in an autoimmune disease characterized by production of antibodies against the TSH-Receptor which stimulates the gland resulting in release of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) producing symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. Elevated T3, 4 produce reduction in TSH via negative feedback.

 

Other options:

 

Option B, C: Elevated levels of T3, T4 are seen in Grave’s disease.

 

Option D: Due to stimulation of the gland, there is Homogenous uptake on RAIU scan.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Graves' disease, low TSH levels are a key diagnostic marker reflecting the increased production and release of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland to reduce TSH secretion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Grave’s disease/Chap 384

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis
Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris

questions.text: A woman with recurrent diarrhea is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Which of the following is not true regarding Clostridium difficile infection?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

 

  • IgM assay cannot be used to confirm a diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin in stool samples.
  • C. difficile, a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus, causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection (CDI) after ingestion of spores of the organism.
  • The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). It is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin.
  • The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.
  • The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins - toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation.
  • The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.
  • Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin  A Or Toxin B or the organism in stool samples. The mere presence of bacteria in stool does not itend that the patient has the disease as clostridoides difficile is a commensal in the gut. Onlly confirmed toxin detection suggests significant infection with clostridoides difficile  This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 
  • Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment: This is true; fidaxomicin is a first-line treatment for C. difficile infection, especially in cases of recurrence.

 

Option B. It is toxin mediated: True; the clinical manifestations of CDI are due to the effects of toxins A and B.

 

Option D. Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris: Also true, this describes the characteristic appearance of the pseudomembrane seen in pseudomembranous colitis, a severe form of CDI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile infection is diagnosed primarily through the detection of toxins rather than IgM assays is crucial for appropriate management. This recognition guides the effective use of specific treatments such as oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin, aimed at countering the effects of these toxins and managing the symptoms of the infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

questions.text: Examination of suspicious stain shows the image below. Which test is this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio

 

The image shows yellow needle-shaped crystals, which are characteristic of the Barberio test. The Barberio test is used to identify the presence of spermine and spermidine, substances commonly found in semen stains. The appearance of yellow needle-shaped crystals is a distinctive feature of this test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence: The Florence test produces dark brown rhombic crystals, not yellow needle-shaped crystals. This test is used to detect choline, another component of semen, and does not match the crystals shown in the image.

 

Option C. Teichmann: Also known as the Hemin test, the Teichmann test is used to confirm the presence of blood and produces dark brown rhombic crystals, similar to the Florence test. It does not produce yellow needle-shaped crystals.

 

Option D. Takayama: The Takayama test, or Hemochromogen test, produces pink feathery crystals. It is used to confirm the presence of blood but is visually distinct from the yellow needle-shaped crystals shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Barberio test is identified by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals and is used for detecting spermine and spermidine in semen stains

choices.text: Sertoli cell only syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Benign testicular neoplasm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sertoli cell only syndrome:
    • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
    • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
    • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.

 

Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm: Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Option D. Orchitis: Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

questions.text: Disorders resulting from defects in nucleotide excision repair include all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT)

 

Explanation:


Ataxia Telangiectasia is not a disorder resulting from defects in nucleotide excision repair (NER). AT is associated with mutations in the ATM gene, which is involved in double-strand break repair pathways. AT-like disorder (ATLD) and other conditions such as Nijmegen breakage syndrome, Bloom syndrome, and Werner syndrome are classified under defective homologous repair (HR) pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP): This is correctly classified as a disorder of defective nucleotide excision repair. XP is characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and increased risk of skin cancer due to inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage.

 

Option B. Cockayne syndrome (CS): This is correctly classified as a disorder of defective nucleotide excision repair. CS is characterized by growth failure, neurological abnormalities, and sun sensitivity.

 

Option C. Trichothiodystrophy (TTD): This is correctly classified as a disorder of defective nucleotide excision repair. TTD is characterized by sulfur-deficient brittle hair, intellectual impairment, and other abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia is caused by defects in double-strand break repair, not by defects in nucleotide excision repair, which is the repair pathway affected in Xeroderma Pigmentosum, Cockayne syndrome, and Trichothiodystrophy.

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smell from nose and nasal obstruction. The image of the finding is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Based on the image showing a significant amount of crusting and given the symptom of foul smell, the most likely diagnosis is Option A, Atrophic rhinitis.

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by a thickening and drying out of the mucous membrane in the nose, leading to crusting, a widened nasal cavity, and a foul smell. The image showing thick, greenish crusts is consistent with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinitis sicca: Is associated with dryness of the nasal mucosa but without the severe crusting or foul smell typically seen in atrophic rhinitis. It usually does not present with the extent of crusting or debris depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Rhinosporidiosis: Is a chronic infection caused by the organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents with polyp-like masses in the nasal passage, which may be friable and bleed easily. The image does not clearly show polyp-like structures, which would be more indicative of this condition.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Is an allergic response causing symptoms like sneezing, itching, and a runny nose, often related to seasonal allergens. It does not cause the thick crusting or the foul smell evident in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of Atrophic Rhinitis is crucial, especially the distinctive symptoms of nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge, along with visible crusting as seen in the provided image. This helps differentiate it from other forms of rhinitis, which do not present with such severe crusting or malodour.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aqueductal stenosis

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly (enlargement of ventricles of the brain) in newborns. It is a congenital condition where there is narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a small channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. This obstruction can result in an enlargement of the ventricles, which can lead to hydrocephalus (accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain). Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker syndrome, and arachnoid villi malformation are other conditions that can cause ventriculomegaly, but they are less common causes than aqueductal stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arnold chiari malformation: Arnold chiari malformation will have downward displacement of cerebellum and brainstem. This is not the most commonest cause of ventriculomegaly

 

Option B. Dandy walker malformation: Dandy walker malformation will have cerebellar hypoplasia with hydrocephalus.

 

Option C. Arachnoid villi malformation: Arachnoid villi malformation is not the most commonest cause

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the leading cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns due to the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of penetrating injury to the eye. A diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was confirmed. Which of the following will be seen? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Panuveitis

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis.
  • Usually occurs after penetrative trauma or intraocular surgery.
  • Both eyes develop panuveitis: the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye).
  • Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.
  • The most accepted theory is the allergic theory which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye.
  • Usual time of onset of sympathetic ophthalmitis – 4-8 weeks after injury.
  • Earliest symptoms in uninjured eye:
    • Difficulty in near vision (Due to loss of accommodation)
    •  Photophobia
  • Earliest sign in uninjured eye: Retrolental flare.
  • Dalen-Fuch’s nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis. These are small, yellow white spots scattered throughout the fundus. These consist of epithelioid cells and are present between retinal pigmented epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.
  • Best time for enucleation (not evisceration) of an injured eye in order to prevent sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye- within 15 days.

 

   

 

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease (VKH) and sympathetic ophthalmia (SO) are bilateral, autoimmune granulomatous intraocular inflammatory conditions with nearly identical findings on ophthalmic exam. Both can reveal serous retinal detachments, optic disc edema, vitritis, and Dalen-Fuchs nodules, but they differ in key facets such as a history of penetrating ocular injury in SO and greater systemic associations in VKH. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute anterior uveitis: Acute anterior uveitis involves inflammation limited to the anterior part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and does not typically follow the pattern seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis, which affects the entire uveal tract.

 

Option B. Pars planitis: Pars planitis is a form of intermediate uveitis that primarily affects the peripheral retina and pars plana. It does not encompass the entire uveal tract as in panuveitis.

 

Option D. Chronic anterior uveitis: Chronic anterior uveitis is a long-standing inflammation of the anterior uvea, typically affecting only the iris and ciliary body, not the entire uveal tract as seen in panuveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after penetrating eye injuries or intraocular surgeries, affecting both the injured and uninjured eyes. It involves inflammation of the entire uveal tract and is characterized by features such as Dalen-Fuch's nodules and retrolental flare in the uninjured eye.

choices.text: Increase in PR interval

questions.text: What is the likely ECG changes noted with the use of new anti-tubercular drug bedaquiline: (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) QT prolongation

 

The likely ECG change noted with the use of bedaquiline is QT prolongation. This prolongation of the QT interval can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including a specific type known as Torsades de Pointes. Monitoring of the QT interval is important during bedaquiline therapy, and caution is advised, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions or those taking other medications that can also prolong the QT interval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in PR interval: An increase in the PR interval is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option C. ST segment elevation: ST segment elevation is not a typical ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option D. QRS widening: QRS widening is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

QT prolongation is a well-documented ECG change associated with the use of bedaquiline. It is one of the notable side effects of this drug.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented with generalized weakness, which increased towards the evening and improved with 5-10 minutes of rest in between. On examination, he also had ptosis and some difficulty in swallowing. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability, which typically worsens with activity and improves with rest. The hallmark of MG is weakness that is more pronounced towards the end of the day or after prolonged activity, and this weakness improves after a period of rest.

 

Key features in this patient’s presentation include:

 

  • Generalized weakness that increases in the evening.
  • Improvement in weakness with short rest periods.
  • Presence of ptosis (drooping eyelids) and difficulty in swallowing, which are common manifestations of MG.

 

In MG, autoantibodies attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. This leads to the characteristic symptoms of fluctuating weakness and fatigability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with small cell lung cancer. It also involves muscle weakness but typically improves with exercise rather than worsening, which is opposite to the pattern seen in MG.

 

Option C. Peripheral Neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy generally presents with sensory disturbances, weakness, and diminished reflexes in a stocking-glove distribution. It does not typically cause fluctuating weakness or specific muscle group involvement such as ptosis.

 

Option D. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder that presents in early childhood with progressive muscle weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles. It is highly unlikely to present in a 76-year-old man as it typically leads to severe disability or death by early adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Key clinical features include ptosis, difficulty swallowing, and generalized weakness with a diurnal variation.

 

Most sensitive diagnosis is supported by single fiber EMG and most specific investigation is antibody tests, such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and anti-muscle specific kinase antibodies.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

 

The amount of radiation exposure follows Inverse Square law which states that the radiation Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Small blood vessels are radiosensitive.

 

Option C: Cancer cells are rapidly proliferating cells are most radiosensitive.

 

Option D: Bone marrow, gonads, bowel mucosa possess high radiosensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: A 39-year-old gravida 4 para 3 woman presents to the antenatal clinic with her last menstrual period being 8 weeks ago. She reports no history of bleeding or pain. During her visit, VDRL-RPR tests come back positive, and the confirmatory microhemagglutination assay for antibodies to Treponema pallidum (MHA-TP) also returns positive. What is the best pharmacotherapy for her condition? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

For syphilis in pregnancy, benzathine penicillin is the treatment of choice. The standard therapy for primary or secondary or early latent syphilis (<1 year duration) before 21+6 weeks of gestation is benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single dose. This patient at 8 weeks gestation with positive VDRL-RPR and confirmatory MHA-TP tests requires prompt treatment with penicillin to prevent vertical transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (Erythromycin): While sometimes used in penicillin-allergic patients, erythromycin is not the first choice therapy for syphilis in pregnancy and has poorer efficacy for fetal treatment.

 

Option B (Azithromycin): This is only recommended if the patient is allergic to penicillin, and would be given as a 2g single dose. It is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D (Tetracycline): This is contraindicated in pregnancy as it can cause dental discoloration and inhibition of bone growth in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Benzathine penicillin is the gold standard treatment for syphilis in pregnancy, regardless of the stage of infection, as it effectively treats both maternal infection and prevents congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

 

The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy.

 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallium. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

 

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

 

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electron microscope: While capable of revealing detailed structures of microorganisms, it is not typically used in clinical settings for diagnosing infections due to its complexity and cost.

 

Option C. Light microscope: Standard light microscopy, typically used with staining techniques, does not easily allow for the visualization of live motility or very thin bacteria like Treponema pallidum.

 

Option D. Fluorescent microscope: Although it can be used to detect specific pathogens if fluorescent-tagged antibodies are available, it is not the standard method for observing motility or diagnosing syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is essential for observing the motility of Treponema pallidum directly from lesions such as a syphilitic chancre. This diagnostic tool is critical in early stages of syphilis when direct visualization of the pathogen can confirm infection before serological tests become positive.

questions.text: A lady presents to the hospital after having a fight with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her health status. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) La belle indifférence

 

This case presents classic features of la belle indifférence, which is a characteristic finding in Conversion Disorder:

 

  • Neurological symptom (inability to speak)
  • Normal neurological examination
  • Lack of concern about the symptoms (characteristic of la belle indifférence)
  • Clear psychological stressor (fight with husband) 
    La belle indifférence refers to a paradoxical lack of concern about serious symptoms, typically seen in conversion disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malingering: Incorrect because malingering involves conscious faking of symptoms for external benefits (like financial gain or avoiding work). Here, the symptoms developed after an emotional stressor and the patient shows a characteristic lack of concern rather and there is no evidence given for intentional deception.

 

Option C. Somatic symptom disorder: Incorrect because in somatic symptom disorder, patients are typically extremely concerned and preoccupied with their symptoms, unlike this patient who shows lack of concern (la belle indifférence).

 

Option D. Generalised Anxiety Disorder: Incorrect because GAD presents with excessive anxiety and worry about various life circumstances, not with specific neurological symptoms. The lack of anxiety about symptoms also makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

La belle indifférence is a characteristic feature of conversion disorder, and is marked by paradoxical lack of concern about serious symptoms, typically occurring after psychological stressors.

 

Comparison of Somatic and Related Disorders

choices.text: Increased FDP, decreased PT, increased antithrombin III
Increased FDP, prolonged PT, reduced platelets

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding seen in Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased FDP, prolonged PT, reduced platelets.

 

DIC is characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation that leads to consumption of clotting factors and platelets. Laboratory evidence of DIC includes prolonged PT/aPTT, thrombocytopenia, and elevated levels of fibrin degradation products (FDPs). These findings reflect the underlying pathophysiology: excessive thrombin generation leads to fibrin formation and consumption of clotting factors (prolonging PT), platelet activation and consumption (reduced platelet count), and secondary fibrinolysis (increased FDPs) as the body attempts to break down the widespread clots.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Increased fibrinogen, increased antithrombin III:  Because DIC typically features decreased fibrinogen due to consumption during widespread clotting. Plasma fibrinogen levels diminish acutely in severe cases of DIC. Similarly, antithrombin III levels are reduced in DIC (not increased), with high-grade DIC associated with antithrombin III activity <60% of normal.
  • Option B. Increased fibrinogen-antithrombin III complexes: While these complexes might form during coagulation, they are not a standard diagnostic marker for DIC. The diagnosis relies on more established markers like PT, platelet count, and FDPs.
  • Option C. Increased FDP, decreased PT, increased antithrombin III: This is incorrect because in DIC, the PT is prolonged (not decreased) due to consumption of clotting factors. Additionally, antithrombin III levels are typically decreased in DIC, not increased.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The laboratory diagnosis of DIC involves a constellation of findings that reflect both excessive coagulation (prolonged PT, thrombocytopenia) and increased fibrinolysis (elevated FDPs) - representing the "consumptive coagulopathy" that defines this disorder.
